Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance encounters a person who is visibly upset and crying about a recent event.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: I was sweeping up the last bits of hair when I noticed Sarah, an old acquaintance from college, sitting in the waiting area, her eyes red and puffy. She looked up and tried to smile, but it was clear she’d been crying. My instinct was to go over, offer a hug, and ask what was wrong—just be there for her, like a friend should. But before I could move, Mrs. Jenkins, my final client of the day, stormed out of my chair, glaring at her reflection. “This is not what I asked for!” she shouted, her voice echoing through the nearly empty salon. I could feel the tension in the room, the other stylists glancing at me, waiting to see how I’d handle it. I knew I had to stay calm, listen to Mrs. Jenkins, and try to fix her cut, even though we were already past closing time. But Sarah was still there, looking so lost, and I felt torn in two—wanting to comfort her, but knowing my professional duty was to the client in front of me. My heart pounded as I stood between them, unsure which role to step into first.
